p.content: This section covers copular, intransitive, transitive, ditransitive, imperative, passive and causative sentences in their basic word order (i.e. not changed by focus, topic, interrogative, or negation constructions). As noted in section
, the typology of
is

case.caseText: SVO, so the basic word order is the subject, then any auxiliary elements, then the verb phrase which consists of the verb in initial position and any complements following it.
SOV, so the basic word order is the subject, then the verb phrase which consists of the verb in final position with any complements preceding it, then any auxiliary elements.
VSO, so the basic word order is the verb in initial position, then the subject, then any complements.
VOS, so the basic word order is the verb phrase which consists of the verb in initial position and any complements following it, then any auxiliary elements, then the subject.
OVS, so the basic word order is the verb phrase which consists of the verb in final position with any complements preceding it, then any auxiliary elements, then the subject.
OSV, so the basic word order is any verbal complements first, then the subject, then the verb in final position.

text.content: The word order changes with any auxiliaries present were discussed in section

p.content: Each of the sentence types are covered in turn here.
Copular constructions include those with a copular verb, if required, or with a perception verb, plus comparatives and existentials.

True copular sentences can have an adjective, adpositional phrase, or nominal phrase following the copular verb. Some languages do not require a copular verb or auxiliary to be present. English examples include
p.langData: My sister is in the hospital
p.content: and
Examples of copular sentences in
include:
As the examples show,

case.caseText: a copular verb is required
a copular verb is optional

p.content: in
copular sentences. The copular verbs are:
As the examples show, there is no copular verb in
copular sentences. There is

case.caseText: not any copular affix on the predicate nominal or predicate adjective either.
a copular prefix on the predicate nominal or predicate adjective, however. This prefix is:
a copular suffix on the predicate nominal or predicate adjective, however This suffix is:
either a copular prefix or suffix on the predicate nominal or predicate adjective, however. These affixes are:

p.content: There is

case.caseText: not any copular affix on the predicate nominal or predicate adjective that occurs when the copular verb is not present.
also a copular prefix on the predicate nominal or predicate adjective that occurs when there is no copular verb present. This prefix is:
also a copular suffix on the predicate nominal or predicate adjective that occurs when there is no copular verb present. This suffix is:
also either a copular prefix or suffix on the predicate nominal or predicate adjective that occurs when there is no copular verb present. These affixes are:

p.content: In contrast to copular verbs, perception verbs usually only allow an adjective phrase following them, except in superlative constructions where a nominal phrase follows a perception verb, as shown in the next section. Some English examples with perception verbs include:
and
Examples of sentences with perception verbs in
include:
Both copular and perception verbs can also occur with an adjectival clause complement, where a sentence or complement clause follows the adjective. These constructions will be covered in section

Comparatives are a subclass of copular sentences. We will consider two types which rate two parts as equal, then comparatives where one part is better than the other, then superlatives. All of these types may normally use either a copular or perception verb.
Comparison of equals can use a noun or an adjective for comparison. The noun equality construction uses a formula meaning
between two nominal phrases. Some English examples are:
p.langData: The curtains look the same color as the walls
Your backpack is the same size as mine
p.content: and
p.langData: Sue has the same hairstyle as Mary

p.content: Comparison of equals can use a noun or an adjective for comparison. The noun equality construction uses a formula meaning
between two nominal phrases.

case.caseText: has a comparative degree word meaning ‘same’ which is used with the noun of comparison in sentences involving comparison of equals, as shown in the following table.
attaches a comparative degree affix or clitic meaning ‘same’ to the noun of comparison in sentences involving comparison of equals, as shown in the following table.

does not have a comparative degree word meaning ‘same’. Only the presence of the two nominal phrases and the noun of comparison with the copular predicate occur in sentences involviong comparison of equals.

headerRow.headerCol: Equal Noun Comparative Degree Affix or Clitic

case.caseText: uses the following comparative conjunction meaning ‘as’ before the second nominal phrase in sentences involving comparison of equals:
does not have any comparative conjunction meaning ‘as’ before the second nominal phrase in sentences involving comparison of equals.

p.content: Examples of sentences expressing the noun equality construction in
include:
The second type of comparison of equals uses an adjective for comparison. This construction uses a formula meaning
between the two nominal phrases. Some English examples are:
p.langData: John is as friendly as Bill
Sue is as fast as Mary
p.content: and
p.langData: David appears as tall as Michael

p.content: The second type of comparison of equals uses an adjective for comparison. This construction uses a formula meaning
between the two nominal phrases.

case.caseText: has a comparative degree word meaning ‘as’ which is used with the adjective of comparison, as shown in the following table.
does not have a comparative degree word meaning ‘as’. Its meaning is simply implied in the adjective of comparison sentences involving comparison of equals.
uses the following comparative conjunction meaning ‘as’ before the second nominal phrase:
does not have any comparative conjunction meaning ‘as’ before the second nominal phrase in sentences involving comparison of equal qualitative adjectives.

p.content: Examples of sentences expressing the adjective equality construction in
include:
Comparatives where one part is better than the other compare two nominal phrases using a comparative word meaning

and include a copular or perception verb. Degree marking occurs with the predicate adjective or nominal phrase. In some languages, this degree marking may either be an independent degree word or an affix on the predicate adjective, as shown in the English examples:
p.langData: John is more handsome than Bill
Sue is a poorer runner than Mary
p.content: and
and
p.langData: John seems less certain of his answers than Sue

p.content: Note that there is an implied copula following the final nominal phrase in the English examples. A more complex type of comparative has an overt sentence in the place of the second noun phrase. These will be covered below.
Comparatives where one part is better than the other compare two nominal phrases using a comparative word meaning
and include a copular or perception verb. Degree marking occurs with the predicate adjective or nominal phrase.

case.caseText: has a comparative conjunction meaning ‘than’ which is used in comparatives where one part is better than the other, as shown in the following table.

does not have a comparative conjunction meaning ‘than’. Only the presence of the two noun phrases and the degree word with the copular predicate signal a comparative where one part is better than the other.

p.content: In

case.caseText: there is not an affix to express the degree of comparison on predicate adjectives. A separate comparative degree word is used with both predicate adjectives and nominal phrases.
one or more affixes express the degree of comparison on predicate adjectives and one is always used with predicate adjectives in comparatives.
one or more affixes may express the degree of comparison on predicate adjectives. However, some predicate adjectives use the affixes and some use the separate degree words in comparatives.

p.content: The comparative degree affixes used on the predicate adjectives are:
The comparative degree words used with predicate adjectives and predicate nominals are:
The comparative degree words used with predicate nominals are:
Examples of sentences expressing the comparison where one part is better than the other in
include:

Now consider comparatives which have two sentences surrounding the comparative conjunction, though the second sentence may be missing the adjective. Like the shorter comparatives above, these compare the qualities or actions of the subjects of the sentences and may have a copular verb or a perception verb or an action verb, along with an adjective that is modified by a degree word or affix. Some English examples are:
p.langData: John is more handsome than Bill is
Sue runs much faster than Mary can run
David appears lots shorter than Michael does
Mary looks prettier than Julie looks
p.content: and
p.langData: John seems less certain of his answers than Sue seems

p.content: Some languages do not allow any part of the second sentence to be omitted and instead always have two full sentences being compared. Also, languages which do not have a separate comparative conjunction meaning
for the shorter comparative constructions will simply have the two sentence parts following one another in this construction.
Now consider comparatives which have two sentences surrounding the comparative conjunction, though the second sentence may be missing the adjective.
In these fuller comparative constructions,

case.caseText: allows the adjective to be omitted in the second part.
requires the full sentence to be repeated for the second part, including the adjective.
has a comparative conjunction meaning ‘than’ which is used in both the shorter comparatives and these fuller comparatives, as shown above.
does not have a comparative conjunction meaning ‘than’, so this type of comparative has the two sentence parts directly following one another.

p.content: Examples of these fuller comparative sentences in
are:
Superlatives are another subclass of copular sentences, directly related to comparatives. They compare a nominal phrase to a group, which may be expressed as

case.caseText: a prepositional
a postpositional
an adpositional
an adpositional

p.content: phrase or simply implied. Like comparatives, superlatives include whatever copula the language uses, or a perception verb, along with special superlative degree marking on the predicate adjective or nominal phrase. In some languages, the superlative degree marking may either be an independent degree word or an affix on the predicate adjective. This is shown in the English examples:
p.langData: John is the most handsome of the boys
Sue is the worst runner (in the class
p.content: and
p.langData: John seems the least certain of his answers of all my students

p.content: Superlatives are another subtype of copular sentences, directly related to comparatives. They compare a nominal phrase to a group, which may be expressed as

case.caseText: a prepositional
a postpositional
an adpositional
an adpositional

p.content: phrase or simply implied.
As with comparatives in

case.caseText: there is not an affix to express the superlative degree on predicate adjectives. A separate superlative degree word is used with both predicate adjectives and nominal phrases.
one or more affixes express the superlative degree on predicate adjectives and one is always used with predicate adjectives in superlatives.
one or more affixes may express the superlative degree on predicate adjectives. However, some predicate adjectives use the affixes and some use the separate superlative degree words in superlatives.

p.content: The superlative degree affixes used on the predicate adjectives are:
The superlative degree words used with predicate adjectives and predicate nominals are:
The superlative degree words used with predicate nominals are:
Examples of superlative sentences in
include:
Existential sentences are similar to copular sentences, except that they use a word or words meaning
or
along with a nominal phrase and usually a location. English examples include:
p.langData: There is a book on the table
p.content: and
Some languages instead have a separate existential verb, such as
in Spanish. Other languages have a whole set of existential verbs which express the position of the object being described.
Existential sentences are distinguished from copular sentences by special existential verbs and/or words along with a nominal phrase and usually a location.

text.content: does not distinguish existential sentences at all. They are exactly the same as copular sentences exemplified above in section
has an independent existential word meaning
or
has one or more verbs used especially in existential sentences, and these verbs fully express the existential alone.
has one or more verbs used especially in existential sentences, and there is also an independent existential word meaning
or
a set of existential verbs which express the position of the object.
has an independent existential word meaning
or
and a set of existential verbs which express the position of the object.
has one or more verbs used especially in existential sentences, along with a set of existential verbs which express the position of the object.
has one or more verbs used especially in existential sentences, and there is also an independent existential word meaning
or
, along with a set of existential verbs which express the position of the object.
marks existential sentences by ___
Existential sentences are also marked by ___

are:

or
used in existential sentences are:

Simple intransitives do not have any complements after the verb, such as in
. Many intransitives have Experiencer subjects instead of Agent subjects, such as in
Simple intransitives do not have any complements after the verb. The subject may be an Agent or an Experiencer, depending on the verb.
Examples of simple intransitive sentences in
with an Agent subject are shown in
. In
a nominal phrase or proper name fills the subject position, while in
the subject is a pronoun.
Examples with an Experiencer subject are shown in
. In
a nominal phrase or proper name fills the subject position, while in
the subject is a pronoun.

p.langData: The batter will hit the ball
p.content: and

Ditransitives can have the second object expressed as

case.caseText: a prepositional
a postpositional
a prepositional or postpositional
an adpositional

p.content: phrase or as a nominal phrase. Some languages, like English, allow both types via Dative Movement, as in
p.langData: The girl gave the gift to her mother
p.content: and
p.langData: The girl gave her mother the gift

p.content: In ditransitive sentences
, the second object

case.caseText: is always a prepositional phrase. a postpositional phrase. a prepositional or postpositional phrase. an adpositional phrase.
is always a nominal phrase. The
can be either a prepositional a postpositional a prepositional or postpositional an adpositional phrase or a nominal phrase. When both objects are nominal phrases, the
direct object
indirect object

text.content: appears closest to the verb.

Imperatives are commands. In
, a subject

text.content: may be missing in imperatives, since it is assumed to be second person.
is required in imperative sentences.

case.caseText: also has a polite form for imperatives. Examples are:
does not have a polite form for imperatives.

p.content: Conditionals have two parts: a condition and a consequence. The condition is introduced by a conditional word, such as
or
, and is set off by a comma. The consequence may be marked by a word meaning
in examples with the condition first. English examples include:
p.langData: If you save enough money, then you can buy that
After you clean your room, then you can play
p.content: and
p.langData: When you eat your vegetables, then you can have dessert
p.content: . The consequence can also be presented before the condition, in which case there is no marker on the consequence, only on the condition. English examples include:
p.langData: You can buy that if you have enough money saved
You can play with your friends after you clean your room
p.content: and
p.langData: You can have dessert when you have finished your vegetables

p.content: Conditionals have two parts: a condition and a consequence. The two can appear in either order.
Some examples of conditionals in
are:
As the examples show, there is no marker for the condition in
, only the conditional mood itself marked on the verb.
As the examples show, the condition is

case.caseText: marked by independent words which occur
sometimes marked by independent words which occur

after

phrasal enclitics which attach to the end of whatever word ends the conditional phrase.
phrasal clitics which attach either to the front of whatever word begins the conditional phrase or to the end of whatever word ends the conditional phrase.
prefixes which attach to the head noun in the conditional phrase.
suffixes which attach to the head noun in the conditional phrase.
affixes which attach to the head noun in the conditional phrase.
either clitics which attach to the beginning or end of the conditional phrase, or by affixes which attach to the head noun in the conditional phrase.

The consequence part of the conditional

case.caseText: may be marked by an independent word which is required when the conditional phrase comes first.
may be marked by an independent word, but it is optional even when the conditional phrase comes first.
is never marked by an independent word.

p.content: This word occurs

p.content: the rest of the consequence phrase.

The subjunctive mood is used to express notions that are supposed, doubted, feared or desired. They are not currently reality. Subjunctives are not used very much in English and the examples look something like conditionals but in first person, such as:
p.langData: If I were in charge, I would fix the problem
p.content: and
p.langData: If I were a man, I would be a soccer player
p.content: In these examples, the subjuctive verb is
and it follows the conditional word
. The consequence is normally in the future form. The consequence can also be presented before the subjunctive condition, as in:
p.langData: I would fix the problem if I were in charge
p.content: and
p.langData: I would like to be a soccer player if I were a man

p.content: Subjunctives are most commonly used in embedded clauses in many languages, following main verbs such as
and
plus the complementizer
. The embedded clause examples will be discussed further in section

The subjunctive mood is used to express notions that are supposed, doubted, feared or desired. They are not currently reality. Subjunctives may look something like conditionals but in first person. Subjunctives are most commonly used in embedded clauses in many languages. The embedded clause examples will be discussed in section
Some examples of main clause subjunctives in
are:
As the examples show, there is no marker for the condition in subjunctives in
, only the subjunctive mood itself marked on the verb.

sometimes marked by independent words which occur

Most languages also have passive sentences, where the Theme or Patient fills the subject position. The Agent may be optionally expressed in some languages, but is not allowed at all in others. If expressed, it may take the form of a PP (as in English with the particular preposition
) or of a nominal phrase, depending on the language. In addition, a particular auxiliary may be required in passives (a form of
in English). English examples with and without an agent phrase, including some showing interaction with multiple auxiliaries are:
p.langData: The glass was broken by the child
The ball might have been hit
p.content: and
p.langData: The ball might have been hit by the boy

p.content: In passive sentences the Theme or Patient fills the subject position.

case.caseText: does not have any passives.
has passives as shown here:

case.caseText: may not be expressed.
may be expressed

a postpositional phrase.
a prepositional or postpositional phrase.
an adpositional phrase.
nominal phrase.

is

text.content: required in passive sentences.

postposition

p.content: used to mark the Agent phrase in
is:
The auxiliary used in passives in
is:

Instead of promoting the object to subject as a passive does, antipassive is a verb voice that deletes the object of transitive verbs. Antipassives are found most often in languages with an ergative-absolutive case system, where the deletion of the object changes the subject from ergative case to absolutive case. It is also found in some languages with a nominative-accusative case system where there is verbal agreement with both the subject and object. In these languages, the antipassive is usually formed by deleting the object agreement affix. Most languages with the antipassive voice are Australian Aboriginal or Native American languages.
Similarly to the subject or Agent in passives, some languages allow the object or Patient to be optionally expressed in a prepositional or postpositional phrase.
Instead of promoting the object to subject as a passive does, antipassive is a verb voice that deletes the object of transitive verbs.
In

text.content: the subject of a transitive verb changes to absolutive case when the object is deleted in antipassives.
the object agreement affix on the verb is deleted to signal an antipassive.
there is a verbal affix for antipassive that signals the change in grammatical roles.
the subject of a transitive verb changes to absolutive case when the object is deleted in antipassives and the object agreement affix on the verb is deleted to signal an antipassive.
the subject of a transitive verb changes to absolutive case when the object is deleted in antipassives and there is a verbal affix for antipassive that signals the change in grammatical roles.

the subject of a transitive verb changes to absolutive case when the object is deleted in antipassives and the object agreement affix on the verb is deleted to signal an antipassive and there is a verbal affix for antipassive that signals the change in grammatical roles.
the object agreement affix on the verb is deleted to signal an antipassive and there is a verbal affix for antipassive that signals the change in grammatical roles.
antipassives are expressed by ___
Antipassives may also be expressed by ___

p.content: The antipassive affix is:

Some languages, such as Tagalog and other Austronesian languages, have affixes on the verb which help define the roles and relationships of the nominal phrases in the sentence. This is a voice change like passive in that it gives emphasis to a particular nominal phrase. The verbal affix marks which nominal phrase is prominent, and may involve a change in word order and/or case marking. For example, in Tagalog the voice marker reflects the role of the nominative argument.

Other affixes on the verb may indicate a voice change similar to passive in that it gives emphasis to a particular nominal phrase. The verbal affix marks which nominal phrase is prominent, and may involve a change in word order and/or case marking.
In

case.caseText: the voice changes are indicated by word order changes instead of by case marking.
when a specific voice affix occurs on the verb, the corresponding nominal phrase is mrked with nominative case.
when a specific voice affix occurs on the verb, the corresponding nominal phrase is mrked with absolutive case.

p.content: The following table shows the verbal affixes used to indicate the voice of the sentence:
Some examples of sentences showing changes in this type of voice marking are:

Causatives add an additional argument to the sentence. Some languages have single-clause causative sentences, where the verb is marked with an affix that introduces the additional argument. That is the type of construction addressed in this section. English and Spanish only have syntactic causatives which consist of two clauses, such as:
p.langData: My mother made me clean my room
p.content: and
p.langData: The other girl caused us to break up
p.content: . This second type of causative will be handled more fully in section

Causatives add an additional argument to the sentence. In single-clause causative sentences, the verb is marked with an affix that introduces the additional argument. That is the type of construction addressed here. Syntactic causatives consisting of two clauses will be handled more fully in section
In

text.content: there is a verbal affix for causative that introduces an additional argument.
there is not any causative verbal affix. Causative sentences consist of two clauses with a main verb meaning
or

or
